Award.AwardTitle: EFRI 2-DARE: Quantum Optoelectronics, Magnetoelectronics and Plasmonics in 2-Dimensional Materials Heterostructures
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical Description: Design and engineering the properties of matter at the atomic level is a new frontier in materials research that seeks to revolutionize applications employing quantum devices. Examples include electronic and optoelectronic devices with improved power and bandwidth performance, which can enable high performance electronics, photonics, and efficient communications. This vision has received a boost by the discovery of truly two-dimensional materials, such as graphene, metal dichalcogenides, boron nitride, and their combinations. These structures provide a compelling material platform for basic research and applications. Because the two-dimensional materials reach the ultimate limit of thinness, being essentially one atom thick, they require new ways of synthesis and assembly into practical devices and they offer new challenges to our understanding of fundamental and practical aspects of physics in two dimensions. This research team focuses on fundamental understanding of the science of atomically thin materials and their stacked structures, seeking discoveries of novel physical phenomena and exploring new device concepts. The team also works on education and outreach projects, supporting undergraduates and public school teachers. Through these research and educational projects, graduate students and undergraduates are educated in a highly interdisciplinary environment. The team also develops an active outreach partnership with the Museum of Science, Boston, to promote public awareness of science and technology at the nanoscale.

Technical Description: The research focus of this interdisciplinary team is on the demonstration of new techniques for designing and assembling two-dimensional van der Waals heterostructures and the fundamental study of novel emergent properties of these quantum heterostructures. Through this research, scientists and engineers in this team develop characterization tools and innovate electronic, plasmonic and optical devices based on various quantum behaviors, such as resonant tunneling. They explore new modalities for tunable continuous-wave terahertz generation and gate-modulation of optical and optoelectronic properties. The research team also investigates the microscopic electronic and magnetic properties of atomically thin heterostructures and develops multi-scale modeling of layered heterostructure devices. The formation of interfaces of unconventional low-dimensional materials systems and engineering of their electronic, optoelectronic and magnetic properties, carried out by this interdisciplinary team, leads to new device paradigms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
EFRI 2-DARE: 

Quantum Optoelectronics, Magnetoelectronics and Plasmonics in 2-Dimensional Materials Heterostructures

 

PI: Philip Kim, Federico Capasso, Donhee Ham, Efthimios Kaxiras, Amir Yacoby

 

Outcomes: 

Modern optical and electronic devices are heavily relied on the technology to confine electrons in extremely narrowly confined physical space of semiconductors. By stacking atomically thin van der Waals materials, we created quantum materials for a wide variety of electronic and optical properties. Our research team focuses on a fundamental understanding of the science of atomically thin materials and their stacked structures, seeking discoveries of novel physical phenomena. We demonstrated several new experimental techniques for designing and assembling two-dimensional van der Waals heterostructures. Employing these systems, we study novel emergent properties of these quantum heterostructures. We also integrated our research works with education and outreach projects, supporting undergraduates in a highly interdisciplinary research environment and promote public awareness of science and technology in partnership with the Museum of Science, Boston. 

Intellectual Merit: Our intellectual research focus was developing new experimental and theoretical techniques for designing and assembling the 2D vdW heterostructures and applying them for various device applications based on these quantum structures. Several notable outcomes from these efforts are: 

  • Demonstration of gate tunable photoluminescent in TMDC heterostructures
  • Theoretical modeling of incommensurate TMDC heterostructures
  • Investigation of superconducting proximity in the quantum Hall regime using graphene superconductor hybrid devices 
  • Ferromagnetic Resonance Spectroscopy of 2D magnetic materials
  • Investigation of the surface plasmon polaritons and vdW structures
  • TMDC vertical tunneling devices for temporal information storage.
  • Plasmonic & optoelectronic 2D devices. 
  • Theoretical modeling of 2D plasmonics by the first principle calculation
  • MoS2 & WSe2 electronic, optoelectronic, & plasmonic devices
  • Imaging hydrodynamic electron flow in graphene with NV centers in diamond. 
  • High-quality factor polariton resonators and polariton dipole antennas 
  • Demonstrating polariton optics with phase change materials 
  • Showing opto-electronic in-memory image sensor with MoS2 monolayer 
  • Machine learning techniques for complex spatiotemporal behavior in 2D Materials

Broader Impacts: This program facilitated the study of emergent physical phenomena that appeared in van der Waals heterostructures consisting of 2D materials. We provided a fundamental understanding of the 2D materials properties and phenomena. Our study enables highly performing electronics and efficient communication by the improved power/bandwidth performance. Through our research and educational programs, we recruited and to trained under- representative minorities, enhancing diversity in our science and engineering research team. We provided many short-term projects that can be accomplished by an undergraduate under the close guidance of a graduate student or postdoctoral fellow. Involving students in research early in their careers served as a tool for retention, particularly for underrepresented groups in science and engineering. We actively recruited and mentored undergraduate students from underrepresented groups and community college students. The team also developed an active outreach partnership with the Museum of Science, Boston, providing public lectures on quantum materials. More than 12 postdocs, graduate students, and undergraduates were educated through this project in the interdisciplinary research environment. They will serve as a new generation of scientists who are deeply involved in both the experimental and theoretical/modeling work with complementary expertise.
